newsitem.title: USA: FDA panel OKs Bristol-Myers' Excedrin for migraine.
newsitem.headline: FDA panel OKs Bristol-Myers' Excedrin for migraine.

text.p: A U.S. Food and Drug Administration advisory panel on Tuesday voted unanimously that Bristol-Myers Squibb's Excedrin Extra-Strength is effective for the temporary relief of migraine headache pain.
Migraine headaches affect 20-25 million Americans each year, three-quarters of them women.

A majority of the panel, 14 of the 17, felt it was safe as well. But the committee wanted to strengthen Excedrin E-S labeling to give guidance to consumers on how to differentiate among migraines and other headaches.
The FDA is not bound by its panels' advice, but usually follows it.
Excedrin E-S, sold since 1978, is the third-biggest pain reliever in the United States. BMS argued that since most migraineurs self-treat, an over-the-counter (OTC) drug is appropriate.
In a survey of migraineurs, BMS found that two-thirds of men and 57 percent of women use OTC's only.
"Self-treatment is the norm, not the exception," said Richard Lipton, a headache specialist with the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and a BMS representative.
